items.title: Show HN: Lldap, a Simplified LDAP Server
items.content_html:
Hacker News: Classic Show HN: Lldap, a Simplified LDAP Server

Hi everyone! For the past year I've been working on a simple LDAP server for user management, targeted at self-hosted servers.

The idea is that OpenLDAP is a pain to install, configure and manage, and on top of that you need a frontend if you want a web UI.

LDAP instead provides a minimalistic LDAP server that supports the subset of LDAP needed for user management and authentication, with almost no configuration required, and a nice UI/API in front of it.

We just released version 0.4 (and 0.3 actually) and it should now be stable enough to use it yourself!

We've had some people using it for tests as well.

Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=32053961

Points: 154

# Comments: 76

Article URL: https://github.com/nitnelave/lldap

items.title: CLI tools for capturing CPU & Memory metrics of running application? (doing HTTP loading testing)
items.content_html:
Lobsters CLI tools for capturing CPU & Memory metrics of running application? (doing HTTP loading testing)

by cliffordfajardo@users.lobste.rs (cliffordfajardo) #ask #performance

Are there any CLI tools which allow you to capture the memory and CPU utilization of a running application?

Background Context:

  • I am doing HTTP benchmarking on two different servers using a HTTP load testing tool. Both servers are written in 2 different languages. Ideally, Iâ€™d like to not write any app code to capture the system information (CPU, Memory).
  • What I envision this looking like: run HTTP benchmarking tool on running server, while the other CLI tool is capturing system info (CPU / memory stats) without any modification to the code of each server

At a high level, iâ€™m wondering if such a tool exists that has the ease of an HTTP benckmarking tool and simply spits out a summarized description of the load measured:
